title: 111_hr3035
content: The "Civil Rights Tax Relief Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. It excludes amounts received due to unlawful discrimination from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Civil Rights Tax Relief Act of 2009" excludes amounts received on account of unlawful discrimination from gross income as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This exclusion applies to backpay, frontpay, and punitive damages received by a claimant. The amendment made by this Act is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON TAX BASED ON INCOME AVERAGING FOR BACKPAY AND FRONTPAY RECEIVED ON ACCOUNT OF CERTAIN UNLAWFUL EMPLOYMENT DISCRIMINATION. Part I of subchapter Q of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section: SEC. 1302. INCOME FROM BACKPAY AND FRONTPAY RECEIVED ON ACCOUNT OF CERTAIN UNLAWFUL EMPLOYMENT DISCRIMINATION. The tax imposed for a taxable year shall not exceed the sum of the tax if backpay or frontpay were not included in gross income, plus the product of the number of years in the backpay period and frontpay period multiplied by the tax determined under certain conditions. The tax imposed for a taxable year shall not exceed the sum of the tax if backpay or frontpay were not included in gross income, plus the product of the number of years in the backpay period and frontpay period multiplied by the tax determined under certain conditions. Definitions for employment discrimination backpay or frontpay, unlawful employment discrimination, backpay, and frontpay are provided for clarity. "Frontpay refers to compensation included in gross income for services that would have been performed in future taxable years if not for a claimed violation of law." The term 'backpay period' refers to the period of services performed to which backpay is attributed, adjusted to the next highest number of whole taxable years if not equal to a whole number of taxable years. The term 'average annual net backpay and frontpay amount' is defined as the excess of employment discrimination backpay and frontpay over the deductions that would have been allowable, divided by the number of years in the backpay period and frontpay period. SEC. 4. Income averaging for backpay and frontpay received on account of certain unlawful employment discrimination not to increase alternative minimum tax liability. Effective Date: Amendments apply to amounts received in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. Section 55(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to exclude income averaging for amounts received on account of employment discrimination when computing the regular tax. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
